title: Moderna, ViacomCBS, Goldman Sachs: Stocks That Defined the Week
summary: Here are seven major companies whose stocks moved on the week's news. Moderna Inc.

title: Chicago Fed Ends Ties With Scholar Who Criticized Black Lives Matter
summary: University of Chicago economics professor tweeted that protest movement 'torpedoed itself, with its full-fledged support of #defundthepolice'. The Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago said Friday it had cut ties with a University of Chicago economics professor who was a scholar at the bank, following his criticism of the Black Lives Matter movement.

title: The Covid Age Penalty
summary: New patient data offers a guide to opening while protecting seniors.. By now it's clear that people older than 65 are the most vulnerable to the novel coronavirus, and the age penalty is especially severe for the elderly with underlying health conditions. This is a tragedy in lives cut short, but it also means that states and cities should be able to lift their lockdowns safely if they focus on protecting vulnerable Americans.

title: France Moves to Embrace Fight Against Corporate Corruption
summary: The country has long criticized the prosecution of French companies by U.S. prosecutors. Now, it's adopting the tools used by them.. The prosecution of French companies by the U.S. for their business practices abroad has long been a sore point for some in France. Now, France's top law enforcement official has released guidance suggesting that it could adopt an approach to corporate corruption and bribery championed by the country it once criticized.

title: Chicago's Walmart Plea
summary: After the riots, the city begs the company it once shunned to stay.. Walmart spent years fighting local politicians to build new stores in Chicago, and it finally won approval in 2010 after paying off unions and liberal groups with a "community benefits agreement." It now ranks among the largest employers in Chicago's heavily minority south and west sides and throws off hundreds of millions of dollars in tax revenue for state and city politicians to spend. But after last week's riots, Walmart seems to be having second thoughts about business in Chicago.

title: Georgia's Primary Fiasco
summary: The voter-suppression charge is false, but it is a warning for November.. Everyone in Georgia agrees the state's primary election Tuesday was a "Complete Meltdown," as an Atlanta Journal-Constitution headline put it. Democrats and Republicans are blaming each other, but everyone will suffer if the same mess happens in November.

title: David Axelrod, Truth Teller
summary: An Obama loyalist opens the door slightly to an acknowledgment of the Russia collusion hoax.. David Axelrod's excuse last week may have been weak but it's wonderful that he offered one. The subject was why, in a CNN-sponsored podcast in February, he didn't ask Rep. Adam Schiff about the implosion of his Russia collusion theory.

title: Pennsylvania's Primary Snafus Could Spell Trouble in November
summary: The battleground state needs to declare a winner on election night.. Pittsburgh

title: Let's Shake on It
summary: For Americans, there is no alternative to the classic greeting.. When we finally get through the Covid-19 pandemic, do we still need the handshake? During quarantine I have thought deeply on this matter. The handshake as we know it isn't going away.

title: U.S. Coronavirus Death Toll Passes 114,000 as Cases Climb in India
summary: Some U.S. states largely spared in the early days of the pandemic are seeing record hospitalizations. • The U.S. coronavirus death toll passed 114,000, while reported cases topped two million, according to data compiled by Johns Hopkins University. Cases world-wide exceeded 7.5 million, and deaths stood at more than 423,000. Experts say official counts are likely low, in part because of different testing and reporting standards.

title: Hertz Can Tap Market Frenzy to Sell 'Potentially Worthless' Stock
summary: Judge clears company's plan to sell up to $1 billion in shares to capitalize on a market rally, despite significant risk of a wipeout for shareholders. Hertz Global Holdings Inc. won a bankruptcy judge's approval to raise up to $1 billion in new equity from a counterintuitive stock rally, a seemingly unprecedented move for a large bankrupt company eager to capitalize on market anomalies.

title: Coronavirus This Week: Some Places in U.S. Press Pause on Reopening
summary: As states restarted economies, cases have continued to mount. As confirmed coronavirus cases in the U.S. surpassed 2 million this week, driven in part by surges in more than a dozen states, some places were citing the increases as reasons to pause on reopening plans.

title: Three on the Third Reich: High-Speed History
summary: In November 1932, the Nazi party lost seats; by May 1933 Hitler had centralized power and bypassed the constitution.. On Dec. 14, 1932,Germany's head of state, President Paul von Hindenburg, a former general, a Prussian's Prussian, hosted a party in honor of Ernst Lubitsch, a German Jew who had emerged as one of Hollywood's finest directors. As two German writers, Rüdiger Barth and Hauke Friederichs, relate in "The Last Winter of the Weimar Republic," another guest asked Lubitsch why he no longer worked in Germany. "That's finished," he replied, "nothing good is going to happen here for a long time." Less than two months later, von Hindenburg appointed Adolf Hitler Germany's chancellor.

title: 'The Dream Universe' Review: Pulling on a String
summary: Physicists once thought a 'theory of everything' was imminent. But decades passed without a clear breakthrough.. Fundamental physics, says David Lindley, has lost its way. "I am ready to declare that research in this area, no matter its intellectual pedigree and exacting demands, is better thought of not as science but as philosophy." His book aims to show how physics emerged out of airy speculation in the 17th century and, in recent years, has sunk back into it. "The Dream Universe" is not a book that will please philosophers, nor indeed historians, though physicists will find the argument a familiar one.

title: Two on Birds: Symbols of the Spirit
summary: A visitation by a bird on the wing simulates literary inspiration itself-bright, fleeting and often elusive.. For centuries, birds have inspired the abiding interest of writers, and it's easy to see why. Birds are one of our most accessible muses. Although not every person of letters will spot a fox, bear or lion in the course of a day, the most casual observer can expect to see a bird, even if it's just a sparrow on a city ledge or a pigeon in the park. Writers are also fascinated by birds, one gathers, because the sudden appearance of a creature on the wing seems to simulate literary inspiration itself-bright, fleeting and often elusive. And for the scribe routinely chained to a desk, birds can represent, as they do for the rest of us, the ideal of escape. As J.D. McClatchy once noted, since "the very dawn of civilization, birds were symbols of the spirit . . . with their uncanny freedom and their exquisite song, they were our sense of soul, the premonition and instance of a life beyond our own."

title: 'Au Revoir, Tristesse' Review: They Order These Matters Better
summary: Voltaire is said to have drunk 80 cups of coffee a day. Proust's madeleine was a mere 'biscotte' in his early drafts.. Norman Podhoretz described the journey from Brooklyn to Manhattan as one of the longest in the world. The trip across the English Channel might be longer. The gulf between France and England is only 20 miles wide, but culturally it's as broad as the Atlantic. On one side, "the Frogs": the guillotine, the bidet and a relentless diet of rationalism, adultery and pastry. On the other, les Anglo-Saxons: the pasty, beef-eating Philistines whose history has been one long Brexit, and who prefer their fellow hypocrites, les Américains.

title: Treasury Yields' Retreat Signals Economic Woes
summary: Investors' bets on worst-case scenarios haven't panned out, but hopes for a return to normalcy have been upended as well. A selloff in U.S. government bonds that pushed yields to the highest levels since March petered out almost as quickly as it started, a sign economic pessimism and aggressive monetary stimulus remain powerful forces suppressing longer-term interest rates.

title: Are America's Elites Really Like the Czar's?
summary: The history of radical regime change facilitated by the intelligentsia suggests elites typically disappear in a purge of the upper classes, regardless of their prior role in the revolution.. Regarding "Violent Protest and the Intelligentsia" (The Weekend Interview With Gary Saul Morson by Barton Swaim, June 6): The similarities of late czarist Russia to 2020 America described by Mr. Morson are sobering. America's educated elites do seem to have much in common with Russia's 1917 intelligentsia: a sense of moral superiority, an affinity for radical chic that leads to the defense of vandals and vilification of law enforcers, contempt for people of faith, a bias toward socialism or anarchy and a feeling of entitlement to leadership and power.

title: Racism's Continuing Blight on Our Country
summary: Orlando Patterson does a thorough job of outlining the extent of racism in America, but he might have noted the failure of many black office holders to elevate the conditions of those who elected them to office. That failure can't be attributed to racism.. Regarding Prof. Orlando Patterson's essay "The Long Reach of Racism in the U.S." (Review, June 6): The numbers of black Americans holding elected office has increased dramatically at the local, state and national level, to include a president who was re-elected. Yet while those office holders have enjoyed individual success, by and large they haven't leveraged their electoral victories into improved conditions and opportunities for their constituents. Inner-city communities in cities such as Baltimore, Chicago and Detroit have continued to deteriorate, with police departments that are frequently charged with abuses and schools that consistently perform below acceptable standards despite municipal governments that have been predominantly black for years. Prof. Patterson does a thorough job of outlining the extent of racism in America, but he might have noted the failure of many black office holders to elevate the conditions of those who elected them to office. That failure can't be attributed to racism.

title: Clear-cutting and Wildfires In the Time of Coronavirus
summary: Clear-cutting increases wildfire danger and accelerates climate change.. "Coronavirus Concerns Loom as Wildfire Season Nears" (U.S. News, May 30) unmasks the challenges California firefighters and the California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection have to face when tackling the looming wildfire season with the additional burden of the pandemic. Even as the dangerous wildfire season is approaching and has already begun in some parts of California, clear-cutting is still a regular practice in our state's natural forests. Clear-cutting increases wildfire danger and accelerates climate change. After a clear-cut, planting same-age and -species trees results in a forest that burns hotter and faster than the diverse forests being replaced. Furthermore, clear-cutting releases carbon stored by older trees and replaces them with seedlings that have little ability to remove carbon dioxide from the atmosphere.

title: CHAZ Poses a Huge Threat To Employment in Seattle
summary: Note to Amazon, Nordstrom, Starbucks, etc.: Good luck in trying to recruit (or retain) law-abiding candidates to work for your company if its based in Seattle.. Note to Amazon, Nordstrom, Starbucks, etc.: Good luck in trying to recruit (or retain) law-abiding candidates to work for your company if it's based in Seattle ("The Seattle Secessionists," Review & Outlook, June 12). What would prevent the Capitol Hill Autonomous Zone anarchists from stopping at just their six-block occupation? The local leaders are inviting the protesters, some armed, to encamp for the long haul. The spread of autonomous and no-cop zones is inevitable unless stopped. Seattle-based companies may have difficulty finding people who want to come to a city where their safety and that of their families won't be assured. Prospective employees must ask themselves if they want to work, live and pay taxes in this type of environment.

title: Facial Recognition Companies Commit to Police Market After Amazon, Microsoft Exit
summary: NEC, Clearview AI and others say they will continue to serve U.S. law enforcement despite increased market scrutiny. The use of facial recognition technology by U.S. law enforcement agencies isn't dead, despite the withdrawal this week of Microsoft Corp. and Amazon.com Inc. from the market.

title: Starbucks, in Reversal, to Distribute 'Black Lives Matter' Shirts to Baristas
summary: Coffee giant previously told employees to refrain from displaying support for movement at work. Starbucks Corp. said it would make T-shirts bearing the "Black Lives Matter" slogan available to employees, reversing an earlier directive not to display the slogan on their person at work.

title: California Is Examining Amazon's Business Practices
summary: State is looking at how the tech giant treats third-party sellers. California investigators are examining Amazon.com Inc.'s business practices as part of an inquiry into the tech giant, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Trump to Speak at Socially Distanced West Point Commencement
summary: Address comes amid clashes with brass about possible military role in dispersing protests over police killings, renaming bases.

title: Stocks Regain Strength, but Finish Week Lower
Nikola, Tesla Map Different Paths to Commercial Truck Market
summary: With a hefty new valuation, Nikola is striking deals with established manufacturers to produce its electric heavy-duty trucks. Electric-truck startup Nikola Corp. and Tesla Inc. both aim to wean the trucking industry off its decades-old dependence on diesel fuel, but the rivals are using two very different road maps.

title: Trump Calls for GOP to Update Platform After Party Carries Over 2016 Plan
summary: Decision by RNC frustrates some Republicans who would like to see updates on issues. President Trump said he would like to see "a new and updated" Republican party platform, after the Republican National Committee said it would carry over the 2016 plan this year.

title: Global Economy Faces a Steep Climb to Recover After April's Historic Dive
summary: Fresh figures show deep damage to business and household incomes that is likely to delay a complete recovery. LONDON-Economic numbers coming in from around the globe are laying bare a stark truth: April was the cruelest month.

title: Hundreds of New York City Businesses Were Damaged, Looted in Recent Unrest
summary: City creates emergency fund providing up to $10,000 to small businesses that suffered destruction. An estimated 450 businesses across New York City were vandalized and in some cases looted in late May and early June, according to the city's Department of Small Business Services.

title: Trump Drives Economic Message as Poll Shows He Has Few Strengths
summary: Some campaign advisers have grown concerned, while others say there is plenty of time before Election Day. WASHINGTON-President Trump has long viewed his stewardship of the world's largest economy as his administration's defining legacy. With less than six months left to campaign, new polling shows he has few other advantages in his bid for re-election.

title: Tencent Takes Stake in Warner Music Group
summary: Chinese internet giant already had interests in Universal Music Group, Spotify. Tencent Holdings Ltd. took a 1.6% stake in Warner Music Group Corp. , according to a regulatory filing, further reinforcing the Chinese internet giant's presence in the music industry.

title: Buoyant Hope and Sinking Despair
summary: In Stephen Crane's 'The Open Boat,' unbreakable bonds are formed on the brink of death..

title: Over 1,300 Chinese Medical Suppliers to U.S. Use Bogus Registration Data
summary: WSJ analysis shows gaps in FDA coronavirus-response program; false address, nonworking number. More than 1,300 Chinese medical-device companies that registered to sell protective gear and other equipment in the U.S. during the coronavirus pandemic listed as their American representative a purported Delaware entity that uses a false address and nonworking phone number, according to a Wall Street Journal analysis.

title: CDC Encourages Wearing Masks, Other Coronavirus Precautions at Gatherings
summary: Guidelines recommend people attending events stay 6 feet apart, wear a mask and use hand sanitizer. The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention urged Americans on Friday to wear masks and distance themselves from others as states reopen and large gatherings take place, including protests related to the killing of George Floyd and events tied to the presidential election.

title: Keeping Your Temper While Stuck at Home
summary: A behavioral economist answers questions about quarantine stress, dieting while working from home and getting over a break-up.. Dear Dan,

title: Aluminum Glut Revives Financial Crisis-Era Storage Trade
summary: Wall Street banks and investors are looking to hoard aluminum, a way to carve out returns at a time of historically low rates. Wall Street banks and investors are joining commodity traders in stockpiling aluminum, an unconventional way to make money at a time when returns on bonds are historically low.

title: A Veteran's View of American Policing
summary: New York's longest serving police commissioner on George Floyd, how the NYPD made racial progress, and good and bad reform proposals.. The killing of George Floyd by a white police officer in Minneapolis led to an eruption of rage and demands to abolish or defund police forces. Ray Kelly speaks as bluntly as any activist about Floyd's death. But he also has a veteran's appreciation for the complexity of race, crime and public order.

title: My Father's Advice: 'Don't Hate, Don't Hide, Don't Be a Victim'
summary: Someone burned a cross in our neighbors' yard. My sister and I were taught to carry on living.. When I was 14, someone burned a cross on the lawn of the house across the street. It was September 1979, and we lived in overwhelmingly white Port Jefferson, N.Y. The targets, the Andersons, were the only other black family in our neighborhood. Ken Anderson, an Army veteran, led the local NAACP. I later learned it was the fifth cross burning on Long Island that summer.

title: Airbnb, New York City End Spat Over Information Sharing
summary: Home-sharing platform will still be required to share information, but on quarterly basis. Airbnb Inc. and New York City have ended their tussle over information sharing as both confront how they will accommodate tourists once travel resumes.

title: For the Best Tortillas at Home, You Need This
summary: Anyone can make tortillas. To really nail them every time, invest in this tried-and-true, cast-iron press.. IF QUARANTINE has taught us anything, it's that many foods we used to purchase can be made at home easily-and better. Among the most rewarding are corn tortillas. The dough's not difficult; what's tricky is getting a tortilla that's consistent every time. The 8-inch Victoria tortilla press, a handsome cast-iron tool made by a family-run business in Medellín, Colombia, makes such an easy job of it that it almost feels like cheating. The design was inspired by the traditional wooden tortilla presses of Mexico, but with greater durability in mind. The smooth, flat surfaces, the heft of the cast iron and a steady lever ensure tortillas of uniform thickness-which means they cook evenly and taste better. The Victoria press makes quick work of empanada dough, arepas and dumpling wrappers, too, and it's hefty enough to flatten sturdy green plantains for tostones (known as patacones in Colombia). Taco night is about to get an upgrade. $20 at target.com

title: Fed Report Says Virus Shock Has Hit Low-Wage Workers Hardest
summary: While employment is seen rising in June, central bank warns of long-term damage from business failures. The Federal Reserve said severe disruptions in the U.S. labor market related to the coronavirus pandemic were hitting workers with lower earnings, including minorities, especially hard.

title: Appeals Court Voices Concerns About Flynn's Bid to End Judge's Inquiry
summary: Two of three judges raise questions about whether trial court judge can be ordered to cut the review short. WASHINGTON-A federal appeals court on Friday questioned a push by lawyers for Michael Flynn to cut short a judicial inquiry into the Trump administration's decision to drop the criminal case against the retired general and former national security adviser.

title: Why Elders Are Indispensable for All of Us
summary: New research suggests that humans evolved to have long lifespans so that older people can pass on their knowledge to young ones.. Like children, older people need special care. The current crisis has made this vivid. Millions of people have transformed their lives-staying indoors, wearing masks, practicing social distancing-to protect their vulnerable parents and grandparents, as well as other elders they may never even see.

title: Maps: How Protests Evolved in the Wake of George Floyd's Killing
summary: Demonstrations have taken place across the country, in large cities and small towns, including some with few African-Americans. Protests sparked by the death of George Floyd are set to continue across the country this weekend. In the two weeks since Mr. Floyd was killed in police custody in Minneapolis, the demonstrations have reached more than 600 places in all 50 states and Washington, D.C., including large cities and small towns-some of which have few African-Americans.

title: Arnold the Grammarian
summary: A tribute to a Journal reader who loved the way words can sing - but not always in my case. The best part of this job? That's easy: readers. Some days, readers like me; other days, they can't stand me; sometimes, they want me to quit the business and get a job knitting hand puppets.

title: Medical-Supply Firm Sues Bank Over Broken Coronavirus Deal
summary: Blue Flame alleges founders received death threats, lost millions in business with state of California. WASHINGTON-A politically connected medical supply company alleged that the improper actions of its bank caused it to lose a $600 million order for coronavirus supplies, ruined its business, triggered death threats to its founders and ruined their reputation.

title: Senate Democrats Ask SBA to Simplify Loan Forgiveness
summary: Recommendations include a simpler application for low-dollar loans that would require minimal documentation and resources including 'how to' videos and a help line. WASHINGTON-Senate Democrats are calling for the Small Business Administration and Treasury Department to simplify the application process for small businesses seeking loan forgiveness under a federal coronavirus aid program.

title: The Best Gins From Japan-and Why They're Special
summary: Think of it as a vacation in a glass: These Japanese gins, meticulously distilled with locally grown botanicals, deliver a taste of the place where they're made.. TO GET TO the Flying Circus, a bar in Tokyo's Shibuya district, you meander through a network of streets lined with upscale boutiques. Eventually you hit a grassy plot across from some train tracks. When you see the vintage camper van serving drinks through its window, you've arrived. Scan the list of 50-plus gins, choose one and ask the bartender which tonic water pairs best with it. Then find a seat in one of the tricked-out mini circus tents and sip your botanical drink as a high-speed train rockets by.

title: Clemson to Strip 'Calhoun' Name From Honors College
summary: As it reckons with ties to slavery and the Confederacy, university in South Carolina will also ask state leaders for permission to rename a building. Clemson University trustees unanimously agreed Friday to strip the name "Calhoun" from its honors college, as the South Carolina school continues to address its ties to slavery and the Confederacy.

title: Police Protests Push Karen Bass Into National Spotlight
summary: California lawmaker leads House Democrats' effort to pass legislation overhauling law-enforcement practices. WASHINGTON-Rep. Karen Bass has been working to stop police abuse and harassment since 1973, the year George Floyd was born.

title: Sentiment Recovers but Has No Immunity to This Virus
summary: Consumer sentiment bounced back in June, but there may be an upper limit if the virus lingers. Americans aren't feeling quite as glum now as they were last month. So long as the economy remains in the grips of Covid-19 crisis, though, their optimism will face limits.

title: Global Coalition of Legislators Faces Challenges Countering China
summary: The Inter-Parliamentary Alliance on China formed last week and now includes more than 100 lawmakers from a dozen countries. HONG KONG-The formation of an unusual coalition of developed-world lawmakers shows how misgivings over Beijing's recent assertiveness have rippled across the globe.

title: Smucker Opts for Wider Guidance Range Amid Economic Uncertainty
summary: Over 200 companies in the S&P 500 have withdrawn their guidance, and more than 90 revised their forecasts. Food manufacturer J.M. Smucker Co. in recent weeks widened its guidance range, in contrast with other companies that have withdrawn their financial forecasts amid uncertainty caused by the coronavirus pandemic.

title: American Banks on Loyalty Program to Back Stimulus Loan
summary: Carrier is pledging its frequent-flier program as collateral in bid to secure $4.75 billion federal loan. American Airlines Group Inc. said Friday that it planned to pledge its loyalty program as collateral for a $4.75 billion government loan as it seeks to shore up capital to manage through the coronavirus pandemic.

title: These Funds Cut the Wrong Way
summary: ETF launches have an uncanny ability to predict the end of an investing trend. People in the investment industry will tell you that the stock market is chock-full of contrarian indicators. One of the best happens to be what those very people think is a good fund to sell you.

title: European Soccer's Experimental Television Marathon
summary: As leagues in Spain and England return to empty stadiums, broadcasters wonder how much technology is too much technology. The stands teemed with color and the air was full of noise when Spanish soccer resumed in Seville on Thursday night-at least if you were watching on television.

title: 'Volatility Is Everywhere': The Market Tactic That's Driving Stocks Haywire
summary: Resume Subscription. Markets were once dominated by bulls who thought stocks would go up and bears who thought they would go down. These days, another animal is on the rise. It doesn't much care what stocks do, as long as they do something.

title: Three Questions With Lanaya Irvin on Talking About Race at Work
summary: A leader in corporate diversity and inclusion says more companies are speaking out against racism because 'the world has changed, and the world is watching'. The killing of George Floyd in police custody has sparked urgent conversations about race and equality, with some of those discussions happening in the workplace.

title: Dion Still Sings of America
summary: A pioneer of 1950s rock has a star-studded new album exploring religious devotion, friendship and racial injustice. It takes a rare artist to help define the early days of rock 'n' roll and to still have the creative vitality to release a star-studded new album in 2020, but Dion DiMucci has done just that. He burst onto radio in the late 1950s and early 60s with hits like "A Teenager in Love" and "Runaround Sue" and has now just put out "Blues With Friends," 14 tracks on which he's accompanied by musical compadres including Bruce Springsteen, Jeff Beck, Van Morrison, Paul Simon and ZZ Top's Billy Gibbons. Bob Dylan wrote the liner notes.

title: Meet Aurora James, a Designer Advocating for Black-Owned Businesses
summary: The Brother Vellies founder and creative director on the 15% Pledge and the back story behind her Brooklyn accessory brand. Raffia. Marabou feathers. Rich wood. Aurora James-the Canadian-born, Brooklyn-based founder and creative director of Brother Vellies-makes sumptuous shoes and handbags out of natural materials. Crafted by local artisans from Kenya to Mexico, her grounded flats, flirty stilettos and whimsical bags appeal equally to bohemian types and pop stars including Beyoncé, who's a fan.

title: For Businesses to Rebuild, the Important Must Be the Urgent
summary: Sportswear maker Fila always meant to get online sales right. When stores shut down, it didn't have a choice.. In 1954, President Dwight D. Eisenhower visited Northwestern University and gave advice now held sacred by business folks.

title: 10,000 Steps a Day Is a Myth. The Number to Stay Healthy Is Far Lower.
summary: While the target has become a default goal for fitness trackers, significant health benefits accrue at much lower levels. Don't be discouraged if you aren't clocking 10,000 steps a day.

title: Is There a Line at Trader Joe's? Social-Media Spies Are Keeping Track
summary: Popular grocery store is crowded in the best of times, that's where watchers come in. Adir Yolkut, a 33-year-old rabbi living in Brooklyn, was preparing for a virtual school singing show when he noticed the tweet: No line at Trader Joe's.

title: U.S. Consumer Sentiment Rebounded in Early June
summary: University of Michigan index rose to 78.9 in the two weeks ended June 10. Americans' view of the economy improved in early June as the country continued to reopen while trying to contain the coronavirus pandemic, according to a University of Michigan survey released Friday.

title: Syria's Assad Faces Growing Pressure From the Street Over Slumping Economy
summary: Demonstrations are rarely seen in government-controlled areas, shattering a taboo on direct criticism of the regime as Syria's currency crisis worsens. BEIRUT-Scattered protests have taken hold in Syria amid growing anger over the crumbling economy, testing the authority of President Bashar al-Assad as he attempts to consolidate power after nine years of conflict.

title: Playing the Market Has a Whole New Meaning
summary: Swarms of willfully ignorant investors are day-trading their way through the pandemic. Las Vegas has reopened, and not just in Nevada.

title: It's Not Too Late to Save the 2020 Election
summary: Avoiding a debacle for U.S. democracy will require getting as many Americans as possible to vote by mail and ensuring that polling places are safe, convenient and plentiful.

title: U.A.E. Makes Rare Public Appeal to Israel: Don't Annex the West Bank
summary: Emirati ambassador to the U.S. warns that annexation would harm progress in normalizing ties between Israel and Arab nations. TEL AVIV-The United Arab Emirates made a rare appeal to the Israeli public, offering closer security and commercial ties between the two Middle East nations if Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu backed away from his move to annex parts of the occupied West Bank.

title: Reopened Restaurants in Michigan: Hands-Free Doors, Sanitizer Tables
summary: Owner of family eateries aims to persuade customers it is safe to eat out in the coronavirus era. ANN ARBOR, Mich.-When one of Michigan's biggest restaurant franchises reopened for dine-in service this week after nearly three months, its eateries had been transformed by efforts to make redesigned door handles and a checkerboard of closed-off booths look as inviting as possible.

title: Biden's Ties to Police Unions Weaken Amid Protests
summary: The former vice president's response to the killing of George Floyd has caused tension with some in law enforcement. WASHINGTON-Joe Biden spent years cultivating close relationships with police unions. Those bonds are now fraying amid nationwide protests against police brutality.

title: Denny's Scrambles to Adjust to a New Restaurant Age
summary: The pandemic has hit full-service chains particularly hard. Denny's chief brand officer talks about how the company has had to rethink its business. When Covid-19 restrictions closed most dining rooms across the U.S., Denny's had to think fast.

title: Today's Logistics Report: Europe Probes Amazon; Unilever Gets Nimble; Steamed Rice Buyers
summary: Today's Top Supply Chain & Logistics News. Sign up: With one click, get this newsletter delivered to your inbox.

title: 10 Father's Day Gifts to Keep Dad Busy Through Summer
summary: Our guide is packed with presents for dads who love to tinker-from handcrafted tools to a Tiffany & Co. bandage box (for DIY mishaps). THIS FATHER'S DAY-reminder to all, it's on June 21, 2020-why not give him the gift of busyness? With many dads still exercising social distancing, they will have plenty of time to tinker away at a new hobby. So present your father with a gadget or two that will enhance his at-home lifestyle and frankly, just give him something to do. From a handsome apron for saddling up to the grill to a birdhouse he can spend the day finding the perfect tree for, here are 10 practical-ish gifts to keep dad occupied this summer.

title: Stagnant Waters Will Be Nestlé's Toughest Sell Yet
summary: Unloading cheap U.S. water brands is sensible, but timing and sustainability worries could weigh on the valuation. A possible sale of U.S. bottled water brands makes sense for Nestlé 's profit and environmental credentials alike. Finding a buyer at an acceptable price will be a challenge, though.

title: Fiction: To Live a Lie in L.A.
summary: In a parable of race in America, light-skinned black twin sisters choose to occupy opposite sides of the color line.. James Weldon Johnson ended his 1912 novel "The Autobiography of an Ex-Colored Man" with the biblical regret, "I have sold my birthright for a mess of pottage," an expression of the mixed-race narrator's knowledge that by passing as a white man he has chosen ease and comfort over the deeper experience of a shared struggle. Over a century separates Johnson's book from Brit Bennett's "The Vanishing Half" (Riverhead, 343 pages, $27), yet the sentiment is unchanged. Ms. Bennett's novel traces the story of light-skinned black twin sisters who occupy opposite sides of the racial divide-one accepting a life of hardship and dignity, the other rising into privilege by perpetuating a lie that leaves her empty inside.

title: 'Without Ever Reaching the Summit' Review: The Common Miracles
summary: What is a mountain? Is it a trophy or a temple?. What is a mountain: Is it a trophy or a temple? Recently we have begun to claim nature's grandest tableaux as prizes. Alex Honnold climbs El Capitan with no rope. Crowded rows of paying customers line the summit ridge of Mount Everest like Black Friday shoppers. Alpinists rush to check off the highest peak of every state, or every continent, sometimes throwing in the north and south poles for good measure. In these cases and others like them, our impulse toward acquisition has overwhelmed the tranquility of the outdoors, creating a breathless set of imperatives: first, fastest, highest. Cameras roll, social-media posts go up, and no one has time for sunsets.

title: China Relies on Persistence in Social-Media Propaganda Push
summary: After Twitter deletes Chinese state-backed accounts, new ones have already emerged, analysis finds. HONG KONG-A Chinese government-linked effort to spread pro-Beijing messages through Western social media is clumsy but persistent, allowing it to adapt and improve over time, according to a new analysis of mostly Chinese-language activity on Twitter and Facebook .

title: Hong Kong Police Move to Stall Protest Revival
summary: Security forces detain dozens on anniversary of pivotal demonstration. HONG KONG-Police in riot gear fanned out across Hong Kong in large numbers on Friday in a show of force aimed at quashing possible unrest on the anniversary of a demonstration that helped galvanize last year's mass protests against the encroachment of mainland China.

title: Mysteries: Blood and Barcelona
summary: An ex-detective contends with a ghoulish killer while investigating the death of an English scientist in Barcelona.. Harry Lawton-an ex-boxer, ex-soldier and ex-police detective-is working as a private investigator in London in 1909 at the start of Matthew Carr's richly detailed historical thriller "Black Sun Rising" (Pegasus, 355 pages, $25.95). An unusual case sends Lawton to Barcelona: An English scientist was killed there, it seems, in a terrorist bomb-blast, after paying a local woman a large sum of money. The scientist's widow wants Lawton to verify the dead man's remains and uncover the facts of her husband's generous gift.

title: Five Best: Steven C. Smith on Music for the Movies
summary: From the author, most recently, of 'Music by Max Steiner.'. By Jon Burlingame (2012)

title: 'A People Betrayed' Review: Robbery Under Law
summary: Within Spain's wildly varied ruling classes exists a long tradition of bribery, nepotism, amorality and greed.. 'This book makes no attempt to suggest that Spain is unique in terms of corruption or governmental incompetence," writes Paul Preston early in "A People Betrayed." And yet nearly 600 pages later-as I glided to the end of this prodigiously detailed and absorbing book-I wondered whether Mr. Preston's avowal wasn't a subtle joke. No, he doesn't "suggest" that Spain is matchless in terms of venality and political ineptitude, at least among the nations of Western Europe. He practically shrieks it from the rooftop.

title: Apple, Google Join Companies Pledging to Change Practices on Race
summary: Businesses announce big-dollar initiatives to promote racial justice in wake of George Floyd's killing. Businesses ranging from tech titans Apple Inc. and Google to toy maker Hasbro Inc. announced new measures and big-dollar initiatives to promote racial justice, as company leaders race to show their commitment to change amid the national outcry stemming from George Floyd's killing.

title: Hollywood Is Reopening, but It's Still Quiet on Set
summary: Crews remain on standby as studios figure out coronavirus-safety protocols, privacy concerns and insurance coverage. The state of California has said film and television production can resume Friday, roughly three months after being shut down because of the Covid-19 pandemic. But few are ready to shout "lights, camera, action" just yet.

title: 'Kettling': From German Military Tactics to U.S. City Streets
summary: A controversial police practice to contain protesters is derived from a German word-and from a move the German army made famous in World War II. In an effort to control the ongoing protests against police brutality, law-enforcement officials in some cities have resorted to a controversial practice known as "kettling." When a crowd of demonstrators is "kettled," they are boxed in on all sides by police. With the crowd corralled into a confined space, the police charge in to make arrests, sometimes using tear gas and rubber bullets.

title: Children's Books: Spending a Day With Dad
summary: Picture books that celebrate fathers and the children who adore them.. The bond between fathers and sons is so elemental that it surely figured even among our shaggy prehistoric forebears. That, at any rate, is the conceit of "Cave Dada" (Chronicle, 34 pages, $16.99), a picture book for children ages 2-5 and their parents.

title: 'The Decisive Network' Review: The Magnum Image
summary: The revered photo collective that helped deﬁne our postwar world was also focused on being a proﬁtable business.. In Susan Sontag's 1977 essay collection "On Photography," the first book by an American critic to take the full measure of still images and their impact on the way the world regarded itself, Sontag writes that perhaps the most important end result of "the photographic enterprise" in the 20th century was "to give us the sense that we can hold the whole world in our heads-as an anthology of images." In the years following World War II, no organization did more to populate that sweeping mental inventory of the planet than Magnum Photos.

title: What It Will Take to Make the Indoors Feel Safe Again
summary: Technologies new and old will soon be appearing in offices, airports, schools, restaurants, retail spaces and sports arenas to arrest the spread of Covid-19 and prevent future pandemics. Cupcake fans walking into New York City locations of the iconic Magnolia Bakery will soon encounter something a little less Sarah Jessica Parker in "Sex and the City," a little more Dustin Hoffman in "Outbreak." Anyone wishing to enter will be encouraged to pass through a cleansing chamber, analogous to the disinfecting airlocks outside biohazard labs.

title: Christel DeHaan Used Time-Share Fortune to Build Schools
summary: Entrepreneur's nonprofit fights poverty with education, health care and career guidance. Christel DeHaan, an immigrant from Germany, was a secretary when she and her husband, Jon, devised a business plan in 1974.

title: Bear Market Drives Billion-Dollar Wealth Firms to Tap Federal Aid
summary: Critics are calling on the wealth-management firms to return the funds. Money managers who oversee billions of dollars in assets tapped federal aid at the height of the coronavirus pandemic, a move that has proved controversial within the financial industry.

title: Please Hold. Shoppers Wait and Wait to Reach Lululemon, Best Buy
summary: As coronavirus accelerates online shopping, some big retailers are struggling to keep up with customers' calls, emails and returns. A month after returning too-small yoga pants he had bought his girlfriend, Mark Quinn still hadn't gotten his money back from Lululemon .

title: A Sexy Air Conditioner? Summer's Unlikeliest Status Symbol
summary: Clunky, view-obstructing window AC units are a thing of the past. The new wave of companies offering well-designed, quiet-dare we say-cool replacements. Last summer, Muhammad Saigol and Erik Rauterkus installed almost $50,000 worth of window-unit air conditioners into New York City apartments.

title: Who Set the Fires in the Twin Cities?
summary: Widespread arson in Minneapolis and St. Paul that was sparked after George Floyd's killing threatens to complicate the Twin Cities' recovery. MINNEAPOLIS-Ever since protesters flooded the streets following the killing of George Floyd in police custody, residents here have wondered: Who burned down so many businesses in the Twin Cities, and why?

title: Amid Protests, Trump Stresses Law and Order on Texas Visit
summary: President says administration will invest more in economic development for minorities and is completing an executive order on policing policies. DALLAS-President Trump pledged to work to address racial disparities in the U.S. but also vigorously defended law enforcement and aggressive police tactics, in the face of nationwide protests and calls from lawmakers for major changes to police policies.

title: College Football Players Have Found Their Voice. Coaches Beware.
summary: Athletes who have been subject to strict social media policies from universities are now calling out racist behavior and holding their coaches and teammates to account. College football players are barely allowed by their coaches to publicly discuss the game they play, much less systemic racism in the U.S. But in the past two weeks, they have suddenly found their voice in the wake of George Floyd's killing.

title: On East Africa's Borders, Vast Jams as Truckers Are Tested for Covid-19
summary: Drivers are viewed as spreaders of disease, and many have no choice but to camp out on crowded roads as they await the all-clear to cross into Uganda. KAMPALA, Uganda-Normally, it takes Abdiyare Muhamed, a 27-year-old truck driver from Kenya, about a week to make the 1,000-mile trip from the Indian Ocean port of Mombasa to the South Sudanese capital, Juba. Now, with African authorities concerned about a surge in Covid-19 cases among truckers, the same journey takes more than a month.

title: Before Catching Coronavirus, Some People's Immune Systems Are Already Primed to Fight It
summary: Research offers hope that could aid search for vaccine. Researchers piecing together how the body's immune system responds to the virus that causes Covid-19 are exploring a tantalizing effect: Some people who have never encountered the pathogen before appear to be able to mobilize parts of their immune system to ward it off.

title: Differences Between New Coronavirus and SARS Show Why Quick Economic Recovery Is Unlikely
summary: New infection's stealthy, swift and global spread means nations must wait on their partners for a turnaround. To see what economic recovery from Covid-19 could look like, some people are examining the closest modern equivalent: Hong Kong in 2003. That is when the territory's economy was ravaged by severe acute respiratory syndrome-another epidemic caused by a coronavirus-and then staged a remarkable comeback in less than a year.

title: North Korea Promises to Advance Nuclear Weapons as It Turns Back to Foreign Affairs
summary: On the second anniversary of the Singapore summit between President Trump and Kim Jong Un, country says relations with U.S. have 'shifted into despair'. SEOUL-North Korea, on the second anniversary of the historic Singapore summit between Kim Jong Un and President Trump, said relations with the U.S. had "shifted into despair" and promised the regime would advance its nuclear-weapons program.

title: Lululemon Takes a Breather
summary: The athleisure company reported worse-than-expected results, sending shares down. That might not be such a bad thing.. High expectations on top of an already-high valuation meant Lululemon had a low margin for error. Its last quarter results appropriately brought expectations down a notch.

title: Fixing a Dollar Funding Crisis for Free
summary: The Fed's emergency dollar swaps have done their job to prevent a market plunge from turning into a full-blown funding crisis at foreign banks. Usage of the Federal Reserve's liquidity swaps-which helped keep greenback-hungry banks around the world stay liquid this spring-seems to have passed its peak for now. The program's success should provide a crumb of solace in any future market blowups.

title: Lamborghini Huracán Evo: Why the EU Is Silencing Screaming Supercars
summary: The Huracán Evo RWD's loud, satisfying engine out-roars its supercar competitors. Dan Neil explains why EU restrictions might put its seismic rumble in jeopardy.. MAURIZIO REGGIANI hates peace and quiet. The chief technical officer for Automobili Lamborghini has spent years crafting its cars' aural signature and expanding their perimeter of outrage, using pure, sweet volume. Please consider the orchestral insolence of our tester, the 2020 Huracán Evo RWD. This updated version of the Huracán mid-engine berlinetta (2014) is powered by the company's barrel-chested 5.2-liter V10, naturally aspirated, with five-octave output now pegged at 610 hp.

title: Uber Says Thank You, Next
summary: Company might look to acquire a smaller rival such as Postmates as it prepares for a new competitive onslaught from Grubhub. Uber shares closed down more than 10% on Thursday, suggesting investors view Grubhub's agreement to be acquired by Netherlands-based Just Eat Takeaway as a lost opportunity for the ride-hailing giant. In the end, Uber could be all the better for it.

title: The Long Arm of State Tax Law Threatens Telecommuters
summary: If your job is based in New York, you may be on the hook for taxes there-even if the pandemic has you seeking refuge across state lines. The same is true in five other states.. The new popularity of remote work is putting a spotlight on income taxes that New York and five other states impose on workers living elsewhere.

title: Rich People Say You Can't Get Rich Investing in Airlines. The Market Disagrees.
summary: After Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway sold out of airline stocks too early, retail investors started buying them indiscriminately. Both may be wrong.. "If you want to be a millionaire, start with a billion dollars and launch a new airline." British entrepreneur Richard Branson's quip has become painfully relevant during the Covid-19 crisis.

title: Auto Makers in Lockdown Test Drive the Modern Car-Buying Experience
summary: Car dealerships are bringing the showroom to buyers. Infiniti, a luxury-car division of Nissan Motor Co. , prides itself on its showrooms. Complete with gourmet coffee and free Wi-Fi, they can briefly double as a living room or office for visiting customers, said Matthew Wilson, the company's director of client experience and training.

title: The Party in the Stock Market Is on Hiatus
summary: Investors are now worrying about coronavirus infections and the pace of the recovery. The stock market lately looked like those kids on the beaches: maskless, ignoring social distancing protocols and ready to party. It appeared to forget about the fallout from the pandemic and was preparing to celebrate new milestones.

title: Battle for Texas Heats Up as Democrats Receive Fundraising Boost
summary: Party sees chance to pick up more seats in U.S. House; HSBC changes lobbying stance as it backs China on Hong Kong. THE TUSSLE OVER TEXAS HEATS UP as Democrats' strategy in the state gets a fundraising boost and the party feels increasingly confident of holding onto the U.S. House in November. The Texas Democratic Party said it hit a new digital fundraising record, tallying about $1.4 million through just digital donations between June 1 and June 7, when it held its virtual convention.

title: Protest Leaders Plan a Summer of Rallies Aimed at Police Overhauls
summary: Organizers push for reallocating police department funding, getting out voters. Many Americans who have taken to the streets in the past three weeks say they are planning for a summer of protests aimed in large part at local governments that are entering their budget-planning season.

title: The Early Coronavirus Warning That Woke Up Wall Street
summary: Before Covid-19 upended American life, the head of a $33 billion U.K. foundation told a collection of money managers how bad it was going to get. The alarm spread through the worlds of finance and business.. The warning was stark.

title: U.K. Economy Shrank 20% in April as Lockdown Hit
summary: Record monthly fall in output recorded in country with one of the worst death tolls from Covid-19. LONDON-The U.K. economy shrank by a fifth in April, a record decline that exposes the cost of nationwide lockdowns on the world's advanced economies.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: GOP Convention Shifts to Florida From North Carolina
summary: Shift comes after President Trump battled with the governor of North Carolina over social-distancing precautions that could have limited crowd size. The Republican National Convention will move its marquee events to Jacksonville, Fla., organizers said, ending weeks of uncertainty after President Trump battled with the governor of North Carolina over social distancing precautions that could have limited crowd size.

title: Zoom's China Ties Under Scrutiny After It Muzzles Human-Rights Group
summary: U.S.-based Humanitarian China found itself shut out shortly after its videoconference marking the anniversary of the Tiananmen Square massacre. Zoom Video Communications Inc. drew fresh questions over its relationship with the Chinese government when it shut down a U.S. human-rights organization's account shortly after its videoconference on the 1989 Tiananmen Square massacre.

title: Bankrupt Hertz Wants to Sell Up to $1 Billion in New Shares
summary: The car-rental company, whose shares surged earlier this week despite its May bankruptcy filing, wants to capitalize on the rally. Rental-car company Hertz Global Holdings Inc. wants to capitalize on the rally in its stock seen earlier this week by selling up to $1 billion in shares, despite a bankruptcy that threatens to wipe them out.
